Primary_Text: Yome ene ati ama?
Analyzed_Word: yomee	ehene	ati	ama
Gloss: jaguar(M)	result_of.M	voice	be
Translated_Text: "Is that the sound of peccaries that have a jaguar after them?"
Comment: The NP ehene ati in this sentence and the previous, and ihi ati in the following sentence, are examples of the "impersonal construction" discussed in Vogel (2021). The full NP in this sentence is yome ene ati, and it consists of a masculine noun followed by two inalienably possessed nouns. Yome is the possessor of ene, and yome ene is the possessor of ati. But ati actually refers to the voices of the peccaries. The reason is that ehene means 'the one/ones affected by' the possessor, the jaguar. That is, the NP means the voices of the ones affected by the jaguar, i.e. the peccaries. In (12) yama is used instead of yome to refer to the jaguar, and since yama is feminine, the feminine ihi is used instead of the masculine ehene; but the meaning is the same.
